entry.et: Middle English, from Old English scearp; akin to Old High German scarf sharp and perhaps to Old English scrapian to scrape scrape

def.dt: :having a thin keen edge or fine point
:briskly or bitingly cold :nipping a sharp wind
:keen in attention :vigilant keep a sharp lookout
:keen in attention to one's own interest sometimes to the point of being unethical a sharp trader
:full of activity or energy :brisk sharp blows
:inclined to or marked by irritability or anger a sharp temper
:causing intense mental or physical distress a sharp pain
:cutting in language or import a sharp rebuke
:affecting the senses or sense organs intensely: as
:having a strong odor or flavor sharp cheese
:having the effect of or involving a sudden brilliant display of light a sharp flash
:terminating in a point or edge sharp features
:involving an abrupt or marked change especially in direction a sharp turn
:clear in outline or detail :distinct a sharp image
:set forth with clarity and distinctness sharp contrast
:major augmented used of an interval in music

entry.pt: sharp keen acute mean having or showing alert competence and clear understanding. sharp implies quick perception, clever resourcefulness, or sometimes questionable trickiness sharp enough to spot a confidence game. keen suggests quickness, enthusiasm, and a penetrating mind a keen observer of the political scene. acute implies a power to penetrate and may suggest subtlety and sharpness of discrimination an acute sense of style.

def.dt: :a musical note or tone one half step higher than a note or tone named
:a character ♯ on a line or space of the musical staff indicating a pitch a half step higher than the degree would indicate without it
:a needle with a small eye for sewing by hand
:to raise (as a musical tone) in pitch
:to raise in pitch by a half step
:to sing or play above the proper pitch
:the act of dealing in which advantage is taken or sought unscrupulously

:a common widely distributed American accipiter (Accipiter striatus) that is grayish above, has a chestnut breast, short rounded wings, and a tail with a notched or square tip when folded called also sharp-shin
